example.voku: Ka sol ane pana tor zara.
example.english: I eat bread every day.

example.voku: Ka sol homi-meke risa kono ama.
example.english: I cook rice with water.

example.voku: Ka fura ure vali poro soma.
example.gloss: DECL fruit be good for body
example.english: Fruit is good for the body.

example.voku: Ka sol ane tera-mela tor zara.
example.english: I eat vegetables every day.

words.etymology: existing root: meat, animal flesh as food

example.voku: Ka sol homi-meke mota eno fira.
example.english: I cook meat over fire.
Fish live in the sea.
The child drinks milk.

example.voku: Ka sol homi-meke una poro ane-tema.
example.english: I cook an egg for the meal.

words.etymology: from suli (sweet, extended meaning) + mela (food) — sweet food substance

example.voku: Ka sol meke ama-homi kono suli-mela.
example.english: I make tea with sugar.

words.etymology: from sela (stone/mineral) + mela (food) — mineral food substance

example.english: The food needs a little salt.

words.etymology: from homi (warm) + meke (create) — create with warmth

example.voku: Ka sol homi-meke mela poro fama.
example.english: I cook food for the family.
We eat together as a family.

words.etymology: new root: nu- (ingest) + -se (liquid act) — ingest liquid

example.english: I drink water.
Taste the new food.

words.etymology: from ane (eat) + vare (want/desire) — desire to eat

example.english: I feel hungry.

words.etymology: from nuse (drink) + vare (want/desire) — desire to drink

example.english: I feel thirsty.

words.etymology: from kara (head/upper) + tela (covering, extended) — upper body covering

example.english: I wear a new shirt.
I need long pants.
I get new shoes.

example.voku: Ka sol pore-soma kara-kosa ken sola hoti.
example.gloss: DECL 1SG wear hat because sun hot
example.english: I wear a hat because the sun is hot.

example.voku: Ka sol pore-soma koli-tela ken afa koli.
example.gloss: DECL 1SG wear coat because air cold
example.english: I wear a coat because the air is cold.

example.voku: Ka vel pore-soma veni-tela poro tema-alati.
example.english: She wears a dress for the important occasion.

words.etymology: from pore (give/put) + soma (body) — put on body

example.english: I wear a clean shirt.

words.etymology: extended from existing tela (tooth → covering) — reassigned: fabric/covering

example.voku: Ka tela ure lenaki en homi.
example.gloss: DECL fabric be soft and warm
example.english: The fabric is soft and warm.
Open the door.

example.voku: Ka sol aze veke-pora poro afa novi.
example.gloss: DECL 1SG open window for air new
example.english: I open the window for fresh air.
The wall has a beautiful color.
The floor is clean.

example.voku: Ka ano-tela savi tama eso nura.
example.gloss: DECL roof protect house from rain
example.english: The roof protects the house from rain.
The house has five rooms.

words.etymology: from mela (food) + zena (room) — food preparation room

example.voku: Ka sol homi-meke mela eno mela-zena.
example.english: I cook food in the kitchen.
The child sleeps in the bedroom.
The food is on the table.
I sit on the chair.
The bed is soft.

example.voku: To nor aze luma-kila ken muhi.
example.english: Turn on the lamp because it's dark.
I travel by car.

words.etymology: from mani (many) + rota (wheel) — many-passenger wheeled vehicle

example.voku: Ka sol pave mani-rota eno kema-loka.
example.english: I wait for the bus at the stop.

example.voku: Ka kema-kosa ure rapi ani mani-rota.
example.gloss: DECL train be fast more-than bus
example.english: The train is faster than the bus.

example.voku: Ka kema ure lomi en vasi.
example.gloss: DECL road be long and wide
example.english: The road is long and wide.

words.etymology: from ama (water) + kema (path) — path over water

example.english: The bridge crosses over the river.

words.etymology: from fore (carry/transport) + kila (device) — operate transport device

example.voku: Ka sol fore-kila rota-kila eko toka-loka.
example.english: I drive the car to work.

words.etymology: from sile (sit) + fore (transport) — sit while being transported

example.english: I ride in the bus.

words.etymology: from move (move) + fari (far) — move a far distance

example.voku: Ka sol move-fari eko loka novi.
example.english: I travel to a new place.

example.voku: Ka kema-kosa vine eno tema veri.
example.gloss: DECL train arrive at time exact
example.english: The train arrives on time.

example.voku: Ka mani-rota zere eno tema he-deno.
example.gloss: DECL bus depart at time seven-ten
example.english: The bus departs at seven o'clock.
The car is fast.

example.voku: Ka sol vike leni eno kema.
example.english: I walk slowly on the road.

words.etymology: from teme (take/obtain) + tina (money) — obtain with money

example.voku: Ka sol teme-tina pana en nama-ama.
example.english: I buy bread and milk.

words.etymology: from pore (give) + tina (money) — give in exchange for money

example.voku: Ka vel pore-tina fura eno tina-loka.
example.english: They sell fruit at the market.
What is the price of this item?

words.etymology: existing root: money, currency, value token

example.english: I don't have much money.

words.etymology: from tina (money) + loka (place) — money exchange place

example.english: I walk to the store.

example.voku: Ka mela-loka tuve mani fura en tera-mela.
example.gloss: DECL market have many fruit and vegetable
example.english: The market has many fruits and vegetables.

words.etymology: from pore (give) + tina (money) + take (do) — execute money giving

example.english: I pay with a card.

example.voku: Ka fura ure tina-puli eno mela-loka.
example.gloss: DECL fruit be cheap in market
example.english: Fruit is cheap at the market.
The car is expensive.
Rain falls from the sky.

example.voku: Ka koli-nura fale eno tema koli.
example.gloss: DECL snow fall in time cold
example.english: Snow falls in the cold season.
The wind is strong today.
The clouds hide the sun.
A storm comes at night.

words.etymology: from sola (sun) + zara (day) — sunny day quality

example.voku: Ka zara ure sola-zara en homi.
example.gloss: DECL day be sunny and warm
example.english: The day is sunny and warm.
The air is cold today.

example.voku: Ka afa ure hoti eno tema sola.
example.gloss: DECL air be hot in season sun
example.english: The air is hot in summer.
The temperature is thirty degrees.

words.etymology: new root: universal ma- reduplication — mother

example.english: The mother loves the child.

words.etymology: new root: universal pa- reduplication — father

example.english: The father teaches the child.

words.etymology: existing root: child, offspring, young agent

example.english: The child is growing fast.

words.etymology: from sami (same) + mama (mother) + hila (child) — same-mother child

example.english: I have one brother.
I have two siblings.

words.etymology: from suni (young) + hila (child) — very young child

example.english: The baby sleeps a lot.
Parents protect their children.

example.voku: Ka fama ane kono eno zara-fina.
example.gloss: DECL family eat together in day-end
example.english: The family eats together in the evening.

words.etymology: existing root: friend, ally, trusted associate

example.voku: Ka sol tuve mani vuna vali.
example.english: I have many good friends.
I love my house.

words.etymology: from ame (water, variant of ama) + zena (room) — water room

example.english: The bathroom is clean.

words.etymology: from ama (water) + homi (warm) — warm water drink

example.voku: Ka sol nuse ama-homi eno tema ine-zara.
example.gloss: DECL 1SG drink tea in time start-day
example.english: I drink tea in the morning.

words.etymology: from kumi (strong/hard) + ama (water) — strong water drink

example.voku: Ka sol nuse kumi-ama tor tema ine-zara.
example.gloss: DECL 1SG drink coffee every time morning
example.english: I drink coffee every morning.

example.voku: Ka sol tuve ti ane-tema tor zara.
example.gloss: DECL 1SG have three meal every day
example.english: I have three meals every day.

words.etymology: from mela (food) + vali (good) — good food quality

example.english: The food is delicious!

example.voku: Ka sol move eko toka-loka tor zara.
example.gloss: DECL 1SG move toward workplace every day
example.english: I go to work every day.

words.etymology: from kema (path) + loka (place) — stopping place on a route

example.english: The stop is near the house.

example.voku: Ka fule-kila move rapi eno hima.
example.gloss: DECL airplane move fast in sky
example.english: The airplane moves fast in the sky.
The boat moves across the sea.

words.etymology: from move (move) + kema (path) — movement along a path/journey

example.english: The trip takes two hours.

example.voku: Ka hila vike eko lare-loka tor zara.
example.gloss: DECL child walk toward school every day
example.english: The child walks to school every day.

example.voku: Ka sol move eko hale-loka ken soma mali.
example.gloss: DECL 1SG go toward hospital because body bad
example.english: I go to the hospital because I feel unwell.
I pay with a card.
Today is good.

words.etymology: from zara (day) + fina (end) — end of day/evening

example.english: I sleep in the evening.

words.etymology: from ine (begin) + zara (day) — beginning of day/morning

example.english: I wake up in the morning.

words.etymology: from kesi (clean, adj) + take (do) — do cleaning

example.voku: Ka sol kesi-take tama tor zara-he.
example.english: I clean the house every week.

example.voku: Ka sol homi-meke mela eno homi-kila.
example.english: I cook food on the stove.

example.voku: To nor sere mela eno koli-kila.
example.english: Store the food in the refrigerator.

example.voku: Ka sol sere tela eno kesi-kila.
example.english: I put clothes in the washing machine.

words.etymology: from afa (air) + tema (time) — air condition over time

example.english: What is the weather today?

example.voku: Ka fama ane kono eno tema-alati.
example.gloss: DECL family eat together in occasion
example.english: The family eats together on the occasion.
I travel with my partner.

words.etymology: from omi (old) + runa (agent) — elder family member

example.english: The grandparent tells stories of the past.

example.voku: Ka neri-runa hele sol kono tama.
example.english: The neighbor helps me with the house.
I have many hobbies.

example.voku: Ka sol vike eno vike-loka kono hila.
example.gloss: DECL 1SG walk in park with child
example.english: I walk in the park with the child.

example.voku: Ka sol lire mela-pine poro homi-meke mela novi.
example.gloss: DECL 1SG read recipe for cook food new
example.english: I read a recipe to cook new food.

example.voku: Ka ama-zena ure eno supo-loka de-tama.
example.gloss: DECL bathroom be in lower-place of-house
example.english: The bathroom is on the lower floor.

example.voku: Ka sol lire sire-kosa eno supe-kosa.
example.english: I read a book in bed.

words.etymology: from sone (sound) + kila (device) — sound communication device

example.voku: Ka sol voke kono mama ulo sone-kila.
example.gloss: DECL 1SG communicate with mother via phone
example.english: I talk to my mother on the phone.

example.voku: Ka fama veke veke-kila eno zara-fina.
example.gloss: DECL family watch television in evening
example.english: The family watches television in the evening.

words.etymology: from move (move) + rota (wheel) — self-powered wheeled vehicle

example.voku: Ka sol sile-fore move-rota eko toka-loka.
example.english: I ride a bicycle to work.

example.voku: Ka sol lire kela-tema eno ine-zara.
example.english: I read the news in the morning.
The kitchen is downstairs.
The bedroom is upstairs.
I travel during vacation.

example.voku: Ka sol sere tela eno sere-kila.
example.english: I store clothes in the closet.

example.voku: Ka sol neke tela-supe ken koli.
example.english: I need a blanket because it's cold.

words.etymology: from kara (head) + supe (sleep) — head sleeping support

example.english: The pillow is soft.

example.voku: Ka mani move-kila ure eno kema.
example.gloss: DECL many vehicle be on road
example.english: Many vehicles are on the road.

words.etymology: from nura (rain) + kosa (thing) — rain protection object

example.voku: Ka sol teme nura-kosa ken nura fale.
example.gloss: DECL 1SG take umbrella because rain fall
example.english: I take an umbrella because it's raining.

words.etymology: from hima (sky) + kura (color) — sky color arc

example.english: I see a rainbow after the rain.

words.etymology: from sola (sun) + tema (time) — seasonal time cycle

example.english: The earth has four seasons.

example.voku: Ka sol pore-soma supe-tela eno zara-fina.
example.english: I wear pajamas in the evening.

example.voku: Ka sol pore vali-tina eko vuna.
example.english: I give a gift to my friend.

words.etymology: from tura (reflection, new root) + kosa (thing) — reflection object

example.english: I see myself in the mirror.

example.voku: Ka sol veke tura de-sol eno ama.
example.gloss: DECL 1SG see reflection of-1SG in water
example.english: I see my reflection in the water.
